comments.userLocation: Lewis Family Farm, Essex, New York
comments.commentBody: Growing affluence, the rise of the man in the gray flannel suit, success in succeeding generations of well trained bureaucrats, has given to many the ability to live distant from family. The poor often never leave town. They never travel. Their more successful neighbors move on. We see this in The North Country. Children with good grades and discipline leave. They do not smoke, they do not drink. They study and make rational decisions. The extended family was often a function of farming, the successful family farm, not affluence. We Americans have shattered ethical farming in favor of something quite different, and obesity is but one result. Our corporate loving government is deeply involved with shattering good food and the families that made it. We are told 80 to 90% of the nation lived on the farm in 1900. Today, it is less than 1%. And 40% are rejected by the military for obesity. That cohort are our least, not our wealthy, for they are seeking a form of stability. They are rarely the mythical patriot that wants to save us from the Axis Powers of WW II. We have a lot of thinking to do. Homelessness is an indicator of who we have become - and where we are going. Single parents, unwed mothers, girls with children from more than one male, these folks are heading for trouble. Who said this is the way to go? Children raising children is apt. We are so disrespectful. Who puts the interest of the child first? Most described are from broken marriages. It starts with the family.
Not throwing money at the problem also will not work.

The gorilla wasn't trying to help the child. The gorilla was the alpha male of the troop and alpha males will often fling around objects (sticks or other objects) to demonstrate their status and dominance.

From the gorilla's perspective, the crowd was probably seen as threatening, especially in the heightened emotional state it was in. The boy smelled like the crowd and the amount of pheromones in the air communicating a fight or flight reaction would have been palpable to the gorilla. He would have thrashed the boy's body to demonstrate his dominance, status and defense of his troop.

Make no mistakes, an adult silverback gorilla is a dangerous, dangerous animal. They weigh 400 pounds and are as strong as 10 adults. An NFL lineman in top physical condition would have been flung around like a rag doll.
Hear hear. Happened to me / my son once too, on the beach at Coney Island no less.
Too bad harambe wasn't so lucky

I am very sad about the gorilla (from the video it appeared he was probably trying to help the child). But I totally refuse to judge the parents: unless you've walked in their shoes, don't claim you would never, ever lose track of an adventurous child for a millisecond - and a millisecond can be all it takes for disaster to strike.

It doesn't even have to be THAT kind of child. I raised a boy who was not particularly adventurous, at least, not any more so than most boys and many girls. (Though he did have a nerve-wracking _climbing_ phase.)

We lost him once for about 15 minutes in a very crowded public place. My heart starts to pound even now, thinking about it - 18 years later. It was the stereotypical case of "looked away for 6 seconds - gone." Both my husband and I were inches from him; my husband was right next to him, and I had backed away a few feet to take his picture, and he was .... just not there anymore. It took literally MOMENTS for him to be swept away in a crowd of moving people. Long story short, we found him in a few minutes, but it was the most harrowing 15 minutes of my life. I knew neither of us had not done anything wrong; neither of us had been inattentive in any way, we were practically joined to that kid at the hip and he slipped out of our control and our vision and was gone LIKE THAT.

Raising a child safely to adulthood is a great good fortune. You have to be attentive but you also have to be LUCKY.
No, you open your home to them. Have you? Or do you not "really want to help the homeless"?

Homelessness is not a crime.  Many of these people indeed have problems.  And they refuse treatment.  But, it’s their right to do so.  And it’s their right to be poor.  It is “us” that is judging them because we don’t like seeing them standing on street corners holding cardboard signs.  I understand that, but I don’t like it when a kid plays his radio too loud on the bus either.  If you really want to help the homeless, then open your home to them.  But, all these other ideas I’m reading seem aimed at getting rid of the homeless so we don’t have to see them and not out of genuine compassion for them.

"Why can't they be like we were, perfect in every way,
Oh, what's the matter with kids to-day?"
--Bye Bye Birdie, 1960
Because modern parents just want to be their children's buddies.  If they attempt to discipline them, the child might temporarily not like it and that would be too painful for mommy and daddy.
That over control of children had its own bad effects later on.  Like a son sent off to military school who learns to bully.

It's tragic; no point in trying to assign blame. I can't help but think, though, that this event is a symptom of the way society's attitudes about child behavior have changed. There seems to be much greater tolerance, for example, of kids climbing all over restaurant booths, running amok in store aisles, and shrieking when they don't get their way. Seems that kids who have been taught to sit still, be quiet, and take no for an answer are in an ever-dwindling minority. Considering how much this type of behavior (or lack thereof)  is exhibited in classrooms, it's a wonder teachers are able to teach anything. Again, no blame in the zoo incident -- except maybe toward folks spewing invective -- but maybe we can use such a horrific event to revisit the notion of decorum and what type of behavior is acceptable in public. And then maybe Harambe won't have died in vain.

So far, it's been funny (see: https://thesoutherner.me/2016/04/11/yokohama-museum-of-art-with-a-toddler/ ) although I work very hard not to let him believe I find it funny. We are working on this behavior every day because it can so obviously be dangerous and terrifying as well.

My sister was the Lamborghini, I was a puttering old Ford. I remember two specific incidences during our childhood. One, my toddler sister kicked away from mom in a pool and had to be rescued. Second incident, she was older, mom was holding her hand, and she tore away from mom and ran across a very busy street. She literally had no fear. Still doesn't, never considers risks even as an adult. I never did anything like that. I was always hyper-cautious. So, yeah, kids are different. And my mother was a diligent parent, yet we almost lost my sister at least twice.
If they can afford a PR firm to handle post-incident statements, they could have afforded an extra hand to help with the kiddos at the zoo. Hopefully they will consider that in the future.

If the child has a 'Lamborghini' under his or her 'hood' then isn't it the responsibility of the parent to act accordingly to prevent danger both to the child and to the people (and animals) around the child?

I'll add that the statement of the family, through a PR firm, is absurd, especially this part: "We know that this was a very difficult decision for them, and that they are grieving the loss of their gorilla. We hope that you will respect our privacy at this time.” I read this as 'sorry for your loss, not respect our privacy,' two sentences which, when one follows the other as they do here, result in making no sense at all.

comments.userDisplayName: John from the Wind Turbine City
comments.commentBody: I had a climber who could scale a floor to ceiling shelf of books. And another kid  slipped out of a motel room after taking off all of his clothes. I found him down a flight of stairs, eyeing the contents of a snack machine. Young kids are fearless, strong and bent of killing themselves, if their mom or dad doesn't die of a heart attack first.

We simply can't hold onlookers or zoo officials responsible for such incidents, isn't it . Under the circumstances, parents or elders, whoever accompany such children invariably have to take extra precautions while taking the children outside since there is every possibility of these children getting missed or ending up in a fatal mishap.

I cite here a fatal accident of a child that happened in New Delhi, India long back. The parents and their son returned back from an outing. Wife went to open the car garage and the husband was at the wheel. Son slowly slipped out without notice and was at the rear side of the car. It was his father's blind spot and unfortunate fatal mishap occurred while reversing the car into the garage. I simply can't image the state of mind of the hapless parents. Even after so many years I am unable to forget this deadly incident. God only knows how much time it took for them to recover. However the child is gone forever.
It looks bad but I agree.  If you have a child who runs off or doesn't listen to a thing you say the first time a leash will do.

Congrats to you! We did the exact same thing for the exact same reason. Worked like a charm. Allowed Miss Houdini to run only as far as the leash went, and we sometimes let her pull us along like when you walk an untrained dog who pulls at the leash, but hey, better than losing the kid or allowing an "escape".

Fwiw, my mother (the grandma) was put on a leash by her mother in the early 30's because my mom could not be stopped from running away (she also could climb over any wall or fence you could put in front of her). So this has been a viable solution to the "active toddler" problem for a long time.

What she said. We did the exact same thing for the exact same reason. Worked well. No damage done to the child or any art work/wild animals, etc. Maybe harness leashes should be required by zoos for all children 4 and under who are not otherwise securely strapped into a stroller. Failure to comply and you are denied entrance to the zoo. Simple.

Every parent has had the terrifying feeling of temporarily losing track of a child. For some reason we feel it's appropriate to keep a pet on a harness/leash but not children.

Used a harness on both my children when they were small in places like Disney, parades, zoos, and traveling where holding hands was not always feasible. They never complained because it allowed them to have mobility with their feet and kept both hands free. Was better than a stroller because it provided both freedom and mobility in a safe range.

Whenever I see a parent using one, I go out of my way to compliment them because I know many times they get negative feedback.

If you have a miniature escape artist, please consider this option. It could save the life of a child or maybe just save you from a few moments of terror!

It appears both parties were negligent.  The barrier is the responsibility of the zoo and it was flawed allowing a nimble child to squeeze under it.  The mother was also at fault for inattention.   This is a wake up call for both parties to make adjustments to prevent any more incidents.

Yep - we resorted to the leash for a few months while my son's motor skills far outweighed his listening skills/judgement.  We got some nasty comments from people about treating our child like a dog.  But I knew I was keeping a very high energy child safe, so I really didn't care what anyone had to say.

vandalfan north idaho
And children slip out of harnesses too! And sometimes children who are quiescent and placid suddenly discover the world! Wham! They're off to the races and even the best parent doesn't have a clue or get a warning!
Grow up! Be a little understanding. Children are NOT predictable. The most watchful and thoughtful parents are unexpectedly surprised.
Yes!  Bang on about that!
As others have noted, there are harnesses and leashes for such spirited children. It is also possible that spirited kids come from equally spirited- that is, obliviously self-centered- parents.

The mother "allowed herself to be distracted", reportedly, by the two other young children she was watching, including a babe in arms.

Your logic sucks. According to you, none of those kids should EVER get to go to the zoo, or the county fair, or the mall, or an amusement park because it's literally impossible to devote 100% of one's attention to three small children simultaneously.

So, given that impossibility, the only responsible choice of the mother would have been to stay home and let the kids watch TV.
So they consulted lawyers before attempting to save the child's life?
Thank you - agree totally.  Just wondering after reading so many of these comments, is "high energy child" the new socially correct way to say "entitled spoiled brat"?

So according to this article - (1) we have a high energy child, (2) placed in close proximity to a wild animal who could harm him (3) who vocalized to his mother that he wanted to go in the enclosure - and the mother allows herself to be distracted?

I think this article proves too much. If you have a high energy child pay close attention to him when he is near danger and/or voices a desire to get nearer to it.

The mother has some explaining to do.

So sad they had to kill this beautiful animal. He wasn't bothering anybody.

But, in light of our horrible civil (tort) legal system - with greedy plaintiff's lawyers and jurors who act on emotion, not fact, the zoo had little choice in the matter. You can bet its corporate attorneys were consulted.
It must be nice to know everything and be able to judge with absolute certainty, even without having been there yourself. Eyewitnesses state that the mother was NOT being negligent.

You can't be serious. You are questioning the whereabouts of the Dad? There's some rule that forbids a Mom taking her kids to the zoo without their Dad?

Yes, it was an accident. How do you know the child jumped? I'll answer for you - you weren't there, you don't know.

The gorilla died. That's sad. It's not the end of the world.

A 3yo child is not responsible or his actions in the same way an adult is. They don't have the cognitive ability to understand cause and effect, nor is intent judged the same way. 3yos cannot make predictions based on experience and facts the way adults can. So, when a 3yo slips his guardians, that is an accident. Everything that happens afterwards continues to be an accident, whether or not the child jumps into the enclosure or falls.

And every 3yo child has had a guardian look away for the split second it would take for the child to slip away. I'd place Vegas money on that. I've seen the most calm and lucid child do the most unexpected things, and again, I'd bet every parent or guardian of a toddler has said at one time or another, "I had no idea the child would have done _____." Spirited child or no.

Also, little kids say crazy things from the moment they wake up. This kid could have been saying, "I want to pet the lions, I want to ride the giraffes, I'm going to go hug the otters." Kids will say, "I will never go near the pool, Mommy" and then end up drowning minutes later. 3yos are not reliable sources for predicting their own behavior. Parents need to make judgment calls, and entering a zoo--where, according to the Association of Zoos and Aquariums, visitors to zoos are primary women/mothers and 2 out of every 3 visitors has a child with them--the expectation is a level of child safety knowing that any kid is capable of losing control; barriers need to be better.

Just because ANY parent wakes up and says to themselves that they will have a wonderful day with the kids doesn't excuse a serious lapse in judgement. Where was the father to assist the mother with this boy?  The boy fought his way INTO the enclosure and who was watching him? That was no accident. He fell? No, he jumped. He got himself to that position to JUMP or DROP into the enclosure which is EXACTLY where he wanted to be.  The mother said it was an accident and no, this was no accident.   That innocent gorilla has paid the ultimate cruel price for irresponsible behavior from the parents.  Please ban them and that boy from ever visiting the zoo again and please make the parents accountable for not controlling or supervising their boy.
